tests.title: Corporate Responsibility
tests.text: There is a growing expectation (1) companies will operate in an environmentally responsible manner. (8) remains to be seen whether voluntary measures will prove adequate.

tests.text: The pace (1) technological change has accelerated to such (2) extent that many industries have been transformed within a decade. Those (3) fail to adapt risk being left behind. (4) is not simply a matter of adopting new tools; (5) requires a fundamental rethink of business models. Some argue (6) we are witnessing a fourth industrial revolution. (7) the one hand, this creates opportunities; (8) the other, it threatens existing jobs.

tests.title: Academic Research
tests.text: (1) is widely acknowledged that peer review remains the cornerstone of academic publishing. (2) the process is not without its critics. What (5) clear is that the system is under strain, not least (6) of the sheer volume of submissions. Reforms (7) been proposed, but implementing (8) has proved difficult.

tests.title: Urban Development
tests.text: The expansion of cities has given (1) to debate about how best to manage urban growth. What (5) be said is that planning decisions made today (6) shape the lives of future generations. (7) such, they deserve careful consideration. (8) is a need for greater public participation in the process.

tests.text: Museums are (1) longer simply repositories of objects; (2) have increasingly sought to engage with contemporary issues. tests.title: Climate Policy
tests.text: (1) the evidence for climate change has strengthened, the political response has been mixed. (2) countries have committed to ambitious targets, (3) others have been reluctant to act. The gap (4) rhetoric and action remains wide. Scientists warn (5) time is running out, (6) policymakers point to economic costs. (7) is unclear whether current measures will suffice. (8) all probability, further steps will be required.

tests.title: Migration and Identity
tests.text: Migration has always been a feature of human history, (1) the scale of movement in the modern era is unprecedented. (2) has led to discussions about identity and belonging. Some view diversity (3) a source of strength; (4) see it as a threat. The reality is (5) most societies have long been shaped by migration. (6) is important to avoid oversimplifying the debate. Research suggests (7) integration works best when (8) is a two-way process.

tests.text: Advances in genetics have raised questions (1) were scarcely imaginable a generation ago. (2) is now possible to screen for many conditions before birth. (3) some this represents progress; for (4) it raises ethical concerns. The law has (5) to keep pace with technology. There is (6) agreement on where to draw the line. (7) is certain is that the debate (8) continue for years to come.

tests.title: Digital Privacy
tests.text: (1) the amount of data collected about individuals has grown, so (2) have concerns about how it is used. Many people feel (3) they have lost control of their personal information. (4) is often unclear who has access (5) what. Regulations (6) been introduced in some jurisdictions, (7) enforcement remains patchy. (8) the meantime, users are advised to check privacy settings carefully.

tests.text: The gap between the richest and poorest has widened in (1) countries. (2) has prompted a reassessment of the role of taxation and redistribution. (6) remains the case that birth remains a strong predictor of outcomes. (7) such, the issue is (8) to disappear from the political agenda.
